entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now Companion â€“ In-App Help (including "?"...
entry.content:
Hi,

SAP Companion can be configured to hide if there is no relevant content for the current screen, so it could be as simple as that.   The issue could also be related to your network, i.e. something blocking content in your network.  You could try to identify a network issue, if one exists, by opening Developer Tools (F12) in your browser when the issue is occurring and see if you can identify an error in the Network tab of Developer Tools.

Another factor that may be causing issues is that an author may have editing control of one or more of the SAP Companion objects that houses Help content, such as Message Bubbles.  This can cause content to not appear.  It can also be an issue if the editing pencil is available in Production so please ensure that the SAP Companion configuration in SF does not allow editing in your Production environment.

I found a couple of other notes in SAP for Me that might help you troubleshoot this issue.

Help content not appearing in SAP Companion
3341562 - SAP Companion: Published content not visible for roles/users with "View Published Content" Permissions Only

Finally, there could also be an issue with integration to Manager, e.g. the CORS server settings, or with SSO, but the fact that content does appear some times makes me think that these would not be causing the issues because otherwise content would never appear.  

So, if none of that helps with your issue, please raise a support ticket using Component ID KM-SEN-CMP and let support have a detailed look.

Regards
Shane

entry.title: Re: How to capture and display comments by dimension comb...
entry.content: @SowmyaBh approach is to use an Analytic Application with an Input Form widget based on your commentary model. Link it to your fact table using common dimensions (Segment, Account, Version, Period) via scripting (setDimensionFilter) instead of a Data Relationship. This bypasses Optimized View restrictions and allows users to view and input comments for the selected cell

entry.title: Re: Fiscal Year Variants in Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
Hello Franziska, thank you for the blog. I have a qustion related to FY for Australia. Here is its definition:

In Australia, a fiscal year is commonly called a "financial year" (FY), and starts on 1 July, ending on 30 June the next year. Financial years are designated by the calendar year of the second half of the period. For example, financial year 2026 is the 12-month period ending on 30 June 2026 and can be referred to as FY2025/26.

Will SCT be enhanced to accomodate such definition? Currently, it does not let me create FY that way.

Thanks and cheers, Maxime.

entry.title: How to Configure Email Alerts for CPI Failures Using SAP BTP
entry.content:
SAP BTP Alert Notification is a service that sends real-time alerts for system events and integration failures. It helps teams stay informed about critical issues without manual monitoring. This PPT covers how to create and configure alert notifications, integrate them with SAP CPI, and send automated error emails when integration flows fail.

Step 1 â€“ Create Alert Notification Instance in SAP BTP

1. Log in to your SAP BTP account.
2. Navigate to your Subaccount.
3. Go to Service Marketplace and search for "Alert Notification".
4. Click on the Alert Notification tile.
5. On the top-right corner, click Create.

6. In the creation form:
     a. Space is optional.
     b. Provide a meaningful Instance Name.
     c. Click Create.
7. Once created, go to Instances and Subscriptions.
8. Locate your Alert Notification instance and click the three dots on the right.                                                                                                        9. Select Create Service Key and save the key.

once open the create service key hear we have mention one meaning full name
and configuration parameters in side just type this one input

{"type" : "BASIC"}

After creation you are got it this type of creation credentials

Step 2 â€“ Create Email Action

1. In the Alert Notification dashboard, click on Actions (top-Left).
2. Click Create, then select Email.
3. Click Next.
4. Provide:
      a. A meaningful Name.
      b. A valid Email Address.
      c. Other fields are optional.

5. Click Create.
6. Check your email for a token message.
7. Copy the token and come to you Alert notification tab click on action and click on email click on confirm Action button and       paste it into the Confirm Token field.
8. If successful, youâ€™ll see a green Enabled status.

Step 3 â€“ Create Store
1. Go to the Actions tab.
2. Click Create, then select Store.
3. Enter a meaningful Name.
4. Other fields are optional.

5. Click Create.
Step 4 â€“ Create Condition
1. In the Alert Notification dashboard, go to Conditions.
2. Click Create.
3. In the Condition field:
    a. Choose Category.
    b. Set operator to Is Equal To.
    c. Set value to NOTIFICATION.
4. Other fields are optional.

5. Click Create.

Step 5 â€“ Create Subscription and Send Test Event
1. Go to the Subscriptions tab.
2. Click Create.
3. Provide a meaningful Name.
4. In the Select Conditions tab:
a. Enable all checkboxes for previously created actions and conditions.
5. Click Create.
6. To test, click Send Test Event and paste the following JSON:

{
"eventType": "MyDemoEventType",
"resource": {
"resourceName": "DemoApp",
"resourceType": "app"
},
"severity": "INFO",
"category": "NOTIFICATION",
"subject": "My Demo Notification",
"body": "Sample event body."                                                                                                                                                                                                     }


7. Click Send and check your email for the notification.
                                            Configure SAP Cloud Platform Integration

ğŸ“ŒBefore you start with this section, you should have:
1. Credentials name for a user that has permissions in the CPI tenant. The default value is CPI_USER.
2. Service Technical Client Name: Credentials name for the technical client created in SAP Cloud Platform Alert Notification.           Supported types are Basic Authentication or OAuth2 Client Credentials flow. The default value is SERVICE_TECHNICAL_CLIENT.
 It should hold the basic or OAuth credentials that we have configured in the previous section.
Once you have done this, follow the steps below:
STEP :-1
Go to the Discover section in SAP Cloud Platform integration and search for SAP Cloud Platform Alert Notification. hear we are got is one Standed structure like flow blow Screen shoot. 

in discover tab once you are identifies this one copy it ,than after go to Design tab click on that particular artifact. Click on the Integration Flow it should look like this.

Click on the Configure button. On the first screen, set a timer to point how often do you want it to run. The default is 5 minutes. look like below image

than after click on Receiver tab below look like this .

we have to fill it hear CI Tenant Base URL , Authentication, Credential Name. this all our CPI credentials Go to BTP hear we are to create service keys You can use the default instanceâ€™s key (default_it-rt_api) if available, or create a new service key of type API (not
integration-flow!) and assign the Monitoring Read role. Save the details from the JSON, you will need them later. see look like under ,

CI Tenant Base URL:- Go to BTP click on API credentials copy hear URL and paste it hear .

Authentiction :- hear go to your Security Material hear you have Create OAuth2 Client Credentials go to BTP before what ever you are create API that credentials COPY it 

Hear copy token url paste it hear , copy that client id, and client secret just paste it hear and one meaning full name you can put it hear my meaning full name i was put it hear CI_USER .

Than after go to More Tab ,look like this below 

Ci Tenant Base Url automatically fetch it hear . Create another Security Artifact for the connection to the ANS(Alert notification service). This is Basic authentication, so the type is User Credentials. Go to BTP inside ANS home page you can open it click on it service key,
Step 1 service key what ever you are created . Come to integration suite go to monitor click  on Security Material click on user
credentials mention that user name and password look like below .

what ever you are created hear Name that name mention in MORE tab service technical client
name.
And SERVICE RESOURCE EVEVT URL IS :- The resource event base URL you can copy
from the service key on the ANS(Alert notification service ) instance:

You then have to add the following path to the URL (that you've copied from the
service key above):

look like above .

Finally Click on the Deploy button. Once the integration flow is deployed, and some integration flow in your tenant fails, you will receive an email with similar content.

Refernce purpose follow below links :-

1. Getting Started with SAP Alert Notification Service for SAP BTP | SAP Tutorials 
2. Connect SAP Platform Integration with Alert Notifi... - SAP Community 

I hope this blog helps you in configuring SAP BTP Alert Notification with SAP CPI. Please share your thoughts or questions in the comments.

entry.title: Rebate and Royalties in SAP S/4
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are on SAP S/4 2022 and we are looking to enable royalties using settlement management.We give royalties to the designer based on product sales. The business volume should be billing amount to customers for those specific products plus rebate. Business also give rebate to customer however it is offline. 

I think, to bring Rebate in royalties consideration, we need to enable Rebate via settlement management.

Here are the steps which we have followed:

1. Condition contract for Rebate 0S10.

2. Condition contract for Royalties 0RS1.

3. Sales order to billing flow, where we have captured Rebate and Royalties in condition type ( for accruals).

4. Ran settlement for Rebate. It has generated a settlement document.

5.Ran settlement for Royalties. It includes the billing document, however it does not consider the Rebate settlement. While running the business volume, we could not see rebate settlement in the list.

Observation- Rebate settlement document does not appear in VBRK. I think, to include in Royalties settlement, it should create SD billing document. Am i correct?

Am i missing any steps here?

 

Regards,

Sumit

entry.title: Additional Preconditions for Procurement Flexible Workflow
entry.content:
Introduction: The Custom Fields and Logic Fiori app in SAP S/4HANA is a powerful tool for in-app extensibility, enabling key users to modify standard applications without requiring extensive technical development. The Custom Fields and Logic app has been deprecated in favor of the Custom Logic (App ID: F6957) app in SAP S/4HANA. In present we are using Custom Logic Fiori app to implement Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) and behavior extensions for released business objects.

This blog aims to assist you in adding preconditions (such as Account Assignment, Plant, and Cost Centre) for Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions Fiori App. These standard fields must be displayed in the F4 help or dropdown menu for selection. To fulfil this requirement, we will implement two BAdIs (Business Context ID: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF, SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL).

 Step-by-Step Process:

Step 1 â€“ Open SAP Fiori launchpad and search for Custom Logic App. 

Step 2 â€“Click on the Custom Logic tile and you will see the below screen and click on Create Button.

Step 3 - Enter the Business Context ID: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF in search input box, then click on Step2 button.

Step 4 - In Implementation Attributes, give the filter value(Scenario ID: WS02000458) using ADD button and save it.

Step 5 - Click on Step 3 button, enter the required details and click on Review Button

Step 6 -It will appear like the below screenshot, now click on Create Button.

Step 7 â€“ After clicking on Create Button, the below screen will appear. Once you click on Publish Button, then you will get Open Code Editor button enabled.

 

Step 8 -When you open the code editor, the below Screen will display.

Step 9 -Click on Edit Button and write your logic here like below code snippet.

Step 10 -Now, test the written code for syntax error or other type of errors.

Step 11 -Implement the second BAdI in the same way using Scenario ID: WS02000458 and business context ID: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL.

Step 12 â€“Write your logic for second BAdI like the below Code snippets:

Step 13 -Save the code and check the Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisition Fiori App, issue will get resolved.

Conclusion: Utilizing the Custom Logic application to implement BAdIs represents the most secure and future-proof method for extending S/4HANA. This approach ensures that your code remains stable during upgrades, is ready for the cloud, and integrates smoothly with Fiori and APIs.

entry.title: Joule Setup for SAP Digital Manufacturing
entry.content:
We're excited to announce that Joule, SAPâ€™s AI-powered enterprise copilot, is officially integrated into SAP Digital Manufacturing. This marks the first-ever availability of Joule in the Digital Manufacturing domain, enabling manufacturers to tap into intelligent, conversational insights right within their production environments 

SAP Digital Manufacturing is a suite of cloud-based and on-premise solutions that enables manufacturers to digitize, monitor, control, and optimise their production operations in real time. It integrates manufacturing processes with enterprise business systems, bridging the gap between ERP (like SAP S/4HANA) and shop floor operations, supporting Industry 4.0 and smart factory initiatives. 

Core Capabilities Supported Scope 

  • Production Execution 
  • Enterprise and Shop Floor Integration 
  • Visual Work Instructions 
  • Quality Management 
  • Manufacturing Analytics & KPIs (via DMi) 
  • Production Orchestration & Monitoring 
  • Resource and Material Management 
  • Edge Integration / IoT Enablement 
  • Sustainability & Compliance 

 

Supported Languages:  

Please refer to the link for most up to date information on languages supported by Joule.  

 please note to validate the data centers supported by Joule here.  

**************************************************************************************************************************

This blog post is a series for Joule Activation: 

  • SAP Business AI â€“ Overview for all !!! (Includes information on Joule Supported Data Centers, Different scenarios during Joule setup, etc..) 
  • Joule - Unified Setup: Bridging Simplicity and Performance (Demo Video to understand the Unified Setup, Joule basics & architecture, how to set up Joule, etc...)  
  • Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition - A Comprehensive Setup Guide 
  • Joule Setup â€“ End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach 
  • Joule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide 
  • SAP Digital Supply Chain 
  • Joule for SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) â€“ Setup Guide 
  • Joule â€“ Getting Started with Document Grounding - setup guide 
  • Activate Joule with SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start 
  • Analytics Insights in Joule â€“ Setup Guide 
  • Joule in SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite â€“ Setup Guide 
  • Joule Setup for SAP Integrated Product Development 

Joule for SAP Digital Manufacturing  (You are Here) 

Blogs - Work in Progress (WIP): 

  • SAP SuccessFactors Joule Activation (Refer to SAP Discovery Centre) 
  • SAP Digital Supply Chain (WIP) 
  • SAP Asset Performance Management 
  • SAP Product Lifecycle Management 
  • SAP Concur 
  • SAP Ariba 
  • and more to be added towards General Availability 

This blog will uncover the steps to activate Joule in two different ways: Section (1): create a Joule SAP Digital Manufacturing as a standalone product (Fresh activation), Section (2): Activating and adding Joule SAP Digital Manufacturing with an existing subaccount along with your other activated / current LoBs landscape  

**************************************************************************************************************************

Scenario 

You want to integrate the generative AI copilot Joule with your SAP Digital Manufacturing application and require information about what to consider when you want to use Joule. 

Use Cases 

The following feature is available for Joule in SAP Digital Manufacturing: 

Conversational search of application help: Ask Joule questions about the SAP Digital Manufacturing apps and processes, and Joule gives you an answer based on the SAP Digital Manufacturing documentation from the SAP Help Portal.  

Pre-requisites 

  • Ensure that you meet all requirements for Joule onboarding. For more information, refer to Prerequisites in the Joule Onboarding Guide. 
  • You have an entitlement for Joule in the same global account on SAP BTP as your entitlement for SAP Digital Manufacturing. 
  • You have subscribed to SAP Digital Manufacturing. 

 

Integration Process: 

If you are activating Joule for the very first time for your SAP Digital Manufacturing system, then we refer to it as a standalone/single setup, as mentioned in â€œSection 1â€.   

In this standalone setup process, you may decide to use the same SAP BTP Subaccount to activate Joule, or you may plan to use a new subaccount or if you would like to add SAP Digital Manufacturing to an existing subaccount and activate Joule that can be used which is a unified setup as described below in â€œSection 2â€. 

What does Unified Setup mean? 

The unified setup of Joule with multiple SAP products allows business users to ask any question irrespective of the Joule client they are in. This approach helps avoid toggling between multiple applications, improves user efficiency, and delivers a more consistent, connected experience across all LoBs. 

Check your setup plan: 

By now, we hope you've selected one of the setup plans. Before we begin activating Joule for SAP Digital Manufacturing, letâ€™s take a moment to understand how Joule works. 

image below explains how Joule works with your landscape integration 

Note: In the current release of Joule for DM, we do not use the SAP Build Work Zone and Cloud Foundry services. This is planned for the next releases.â€¯â€¯â€¯ 

Now, since you have a clear understanding about Digital Manufacturing and how Joule works now it is time for us to start the integration process:  

Let us have a look at the steps involved for the integration: 

**************************************************************************************************************************

Integrating Joule  

  • Step 1: Setup Plan:  
    • Section 1: New Digital Manufacturing setup with no prior Joule setup. 
    • Section 2: You have an existing Joule subaccount, and you want to enable Joule for Digital Manufacturing 

*************************************************************************************************************************

Step 1: Setup Plan 

Section 1: New Digital Manufacturing setup with no prior Joule setup. 

If you already have some experience with SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) we request you to follow the steps in this blog - Joule Setup â€“ End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach. In this blog, please check Section 2 (Check your SAP BTP Account for Joule Entitlements. 

If this is your first time using the SAP DM (Digital Manufacturing) platform and you're unsure how to proceed with the activation, donâ€™t worry - weâ€™ve got you covered. Just follow the steps below to activate Joule for SAP DM easily.â€¯ 

Fresh Digital Manufacturing setup â€“ no existing Joule configuration 

  1. Create the Subaccount and choose the relevant Data Centre 
  2. Set up Trust Configuration with SAP Cloud Identity Service 
  3. Add Entitlements 
  4. Run the Booster and Integrations with the Product SAP Digital Manufacturing 
    • Note: Choose the SAP Digital Manufacturing Test as product to enable Joule in your SAP Digital Manufacturing quality tenant. 
  5. Add the role â€œJoule_Userâ€ from the dmc application to a role collection 
    • Note: Assign those business users to the role collection that needs to interact with Joule. 
  6. Configure trusted domains in identity authentication for the SAP Digital Manufacturing domain 
    • Note: For more information, refer to Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant. 
  7. Configure a trusted domain in SAP BTP Cockpit for the same SAP Digital Manufacturing system
    • Note: For more information, refer to Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP. 
  8. Add the DM_USER User Role Collection to Launch the Joule
  9. See Joule in Action 

Step (1): Create the Subaccount and choose the relevant Data Centre 

Check this blog and follow step No â€“ 5 

Check this blog and follow step No â€“ 4 

Step (2): Set up Trust Configuration with SAP Cloud Identity Service 

Check this blog and follow step No â€“ 7 

 

 

 

Step (3): Add Entitlements 

Check this blog and follow step No â€“ 8  

 

 

Step (4): Run the Booster and Integrations with the Product SAP Digital Manufacturing 

The complete setup process is documented in this blog. Step No. 10 explains the process. For simplification, we have the simplified steps and images below.â€¯ 

  • Click on Global Account -> Select Booster -> Search for Joule -> Run the Boosterâ€¯ 

 

The system will validate the entitlements required. Once itâ€™s green, you can click on Nextâ€¯ 

Select the SAP BTP Subaccount and click on Nextâ€¯ 

Select Integrations, you will be able to see the options for SAP IPD, select it, and click on Nextâ€¯ 

 

 

Once you select the DM System, you can click on Next, review the selections, and click on Finish. The booster will take 5-9 minutes to activate Joule and set up the integrations with your DM system.â€¯ 

Joule will now return the success message after the integrations are completed. You can validate this setup by navigating to Systems and Formation, searching for the Joule formation that will be created for your setup, as shown below.â€¯â€¯ 

Step (5): Add the role â€œJoule_Userâ€ from the dmc application to a role collection 

  • After the booster run has completed and formation checks, add the role â€œJoule_Userâ€ from the dmc application to a role collection.  
  • Assign those business users to the role collection that needs to interact with Joule. 

Click on Subaccount -> Role Collections -> Create -> Joule_User -> Edit -> Role Name 

 

Step (6): Configure trusted domains in identity authentication for the SAP Digital Manufacturing domain 

  • For more information, refer to Configure Trust to the Identity Authentication Tenant. 

Open Cloud Identity Services -> click on Applications & Resources -> External Services -> Trusted Domains -> Add 

 

Step (7): Configure a trusted domain in SAP BTP Cockpit for the same SAP Digital Manufacturing system 

  • For more information, refer to Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP. 

Open Sub Account -> Security -> Settings -> Trusted Domains -> Add  

Step (8): Assign the role in Subaccount to launch the Joule 

Open Sub Account -> Security -> Role Collection > Create -> Add (DM_ROLE) 

 

 Step (9)  See Joule in Action

Congratulations on successfully setting up the SAP DM Standalone system!â€¯ 

â€¯ 
Now, letâ€™s walk through how to add SAP DM to your existing subaccount alongside your other active Lines of Business (LoBs).â€¯ 

Step 1: Setup Plan 

Section 2: You have an existing Joule subaccount, and you want to enable Joule for DM. In this option, we will show you how to activate DM in the context of an existing Joule formation. Within your SAP BTP Global Account, navigate to System Landscapes, click on Formationsâ€¯ 

Search for the Joule formation you have already set up. In my case, â€œI am using one of the existing formations, which has multiple SAP products connected to one Joule instance, as shown belowâ€. You can click on Include Systems. â€¯ 

 

In the new window, filter for SAP Digital Manufacturing and click on Next step.â€¯â€¯ 

 

Select the option â€œEnable Capability Deploymentâ€ and â€œEnable the Joule Icon in Integrated Systemâ€ and click on Review 

 

Validate the selections and click on Include.â€¯â€¯ 

The process may take 5 to 8 minutes to complete, and you should be able to see the synchronizing option, as shown image below. 

 

Once the status turns green and Ready, we are good to use Joule with Digital Manufacturing capabilities.  

Congratulations on successfully setting up SAP Digital Manufacturing with the Unified Approach! 

In a similar approach, you may use Joule with a unified experience in other SAP products that you have integrated in the same subaccount. 

If you have any questions about the setup, you can reach us at SAP_AI_RIG@sap.com  

Thank you for staying connected with our blog and successfully activating Joule for SAP Digital Manufacturing ! 

 
We hope youâ€™ve had an exciting experience exploring the power of Joule, your intelligent business companion. From insightful decisions to streamlined processes, we trust youâ€™re already seeing the incredible value Joule brings to your day-to-day work. 

Hereâ€™s smarter, faster, and more impactful outcomes powered by Joule! ğŸš€

entry.title: Integrate custom fields in standard SAP IBP Extractors
entry.content:
Introduction:

Integrating custom fields into standard SAP IBP extractors is a common requirement during SAP IBP Integration. While SAP provides robust staging and extraction frameworks, enabling these custom fields to flow seamlessly from ECC or S/4HANA into IBP requires careful configuration and enhancement.

This guide walks through the step-by-step process to enhance the standard IBP data flow by adding a custom field (ZZREGION) to the Location Master Data. From extending the staging table to modifying the extractor logic and enabling the field in the data source, each step ensures that your custom attribute is properly handled and integrated in IBP.

Steps to perform to include the custom fields in the standard IBP extractor:

Step 1: Enhancing the staging table:

  • Identify the relevant staging table. In our case, it's /IBP/LOC_EXT. 
  • Create a new append structure in transaction SE11 with the relevant name. 
  • Add the required fields. 
  • Save and activate the structure. 

  • Return to the table in SE11 and you will see the new field at the end.

Step 2: Populating the values in the new fields. 

To enable the automatic data population for the custom fields in the staging table, we need to implement the BADIs provided by SAP. We have different BADIs for different staging tables. 

In our case, to populate the ZZREGION field, we will use /IBP/ECC_SAVE_LOCATION. You can check the details in SE18. 

  • Create a new implementation. e.g. Z_IBP_LOC_ENHANCEMENT.
  • Implementing class will be created. I'm taking an assumption that you are aware of the BADI implementation steps.
  • Implement the method SAVE_LOC in the implementation class with your custom logic to populate the field ZZREGION. This method is triggered before saving the data into the staging table /IBP/LOC_EXT. 
  • Activate the method and class.
  • Now, the custom implementation will populate the field ZZREGION whenever the Location Master Data Integration will be triggered.
  • To test this, you can use the transaction /IBP/ECC_INT_LOC. It will trigger the Location Master Data integration process. 

Now we can see the custom field value in the staging table /IBP/LOC_EXT, but it's not all. The real purpose of this implementation is to send this custom field information to IBP. We use the CI-DS tool to send this information from the SAP ECC or S4 HANA system. CI-DS triggers the extractors in the SAP system to get all the required data. 

In the next step, we will update the SAP standard extractor to send the custom field value of ZZREGION to IBP. 

Step 3: Enhance the Extractor's Structure: 

Every extractor has a defined output structure, and upon triggering, the extractor structure field values are collected and transferred to IBP. For location master data extractor /IBP/LOCATION_ATTR is used.

Follow the steps below to add the ZZREGION field to the extractor /IBP/LOCATION_ATTR:

  • Go to transaction RSA2, Extraction tab, to find the extractor output structure.
  • For /IBP/LOCATION_ATTR it is /IBP/S_ETS_LOCATION_ATTR_PUB

  • You can also find other details related to the extractor, like the Extraction Method and technical objects to perform the extraction. In this, it's a function module /IBP/ETS_RSAX_BIW_GET_MASTER_D.
  • Following the same steps (creation of a new append structure) that we did for staging table enhancement, we will add the field ZZREGION in the extractor structure. 

Step 4: Extracting the custom field value for the extractor

As it is a custom field, populating it during the extractor execution is also our responsibility. In order to populate the ZZREGION during extractor execution, we need to implement the standard BADI /IBP/BADI_ES_ETS_SELECTION. 

It allows us to dynamically modify the field value of the extractor, telling it which columns to provide in the result. 

  • Using the SE18 or SE19, create the BADI implementation.
  • Implementation class will be created. 
  • Implement the method MODIFY_DATA_PACKAGE in the implementation class with the logic to retrieve the value from the staging table /IBP/LOC_EXT~ZZREGIO. 
  • This BADI is used by all the standard SAP extractors, hence the custom implementation logic can also be triggered for other extractors as well where it is not relevant. It's important to add a check on the extractor name at the very beginning of the program. The extractor name is available in the importing parameter iv_selection_object_id.
CASE iv_selection_object_id.
  WHEN zcl_im_badi_extractor=>'/IBP/PRODUCT_ATTR'.
    "Call the method to update the fields for extractor /IBP/PRODUCT_ATTR
    lo_obj->modify_/ibp/product_attr( CHANGING ct_itab = ct_itab ).

  WHEN zcl_im_badi_extractor=>'/IBP/LOCATIONPRODUCT_ATTR'.
    "Call the method to update the fields for extractor /IBP/LOCATIONPRODUCT_ATTR
    lo_obj->modify_/ibp/locproduct_attr( CHANGING ct_itab = ct_itab ).

  WHEN zcl_im_badi_extractor=>'/IBP/LOCATION_ATTR'.
    "Call the method to update the fields for extractor /IBP/LOCATION_ATTR
    lo_obj->modify_/ibp/location_attr( CHANGING ct_itab = ct_itab ).
 WHEN OTHERS.
ENDCASE.
  • The value of ZZREGION will be returned in the changing parameter CT_ITAB of the method MODIFY_DATA_PACKAGE. It's tricky to update the CT_ITAB as it has no specific type. It's created as a table only and it's structure is defined at run time as per the extractor being processed. In order to update this table, we can create a temporary table with the same structure it will have at run time(As we know our logic will be triggered only for extractor /IBP/LOCATION_ATTR). Example:
    DATA: li_loc_ext  TYPE TABLE OF /ibp/s_ets_location_attr_pub.
    li_loc_ext = ct_itab.
    "We update our run time information to li_loc_ext, and at the end it's copied back to ct_itab. 
    ct_itab = li_loc_ext.
  • Activate the method and class. 

We added our custom field ZZREGION to the staging table. Populated it with our custom logic. Updated the extractor to retrieve this field during the extraction, and you might still not see it after executing the extractor in SAP. 

The reason is by default new fields added to the extractor structure are hidden. To check this go to transaction RSA6 and find the Data Source /IBP/LOCATION_ATTR. Upon double-clicking it, you will see the list of fields. For every field, there would be 4 checkboxes: "Selection", "Hide field", "Inversion", "Field only".  Scroll down and find the ZZREGION "Hide field" checkbox would be selected. Uncheck it and save. 

Now, if you test your extractor again in transaction RSA3 or /IBP/ETS_REPL_TEST, you would see the values of the field ZZREGION. 

** SAP also provides some additional custom attribute fields(CUST_ATTRx), which could be used in some cases. It's always a good idea to look for the possibility of using them.

entry.title: Implementing custom compensation statements
entry.content:
Unlike standard statements, creating a custom statement that meets all client requirements while also looks visually appealing is quite an innovative activity.

 It involves detailed break-up of every pay component and fields, while also reflecting companyâ€™s identity through custom logos, various colors, and desired formatting.

Now, let's explore the code.

Declaring parameters name to be used in statements

<xsl:param name="statementTitle"/>
	<xsl:param name="customLogoURL"/>
	<xsl:param name="companyLogoURLParam"/>
	<xsl:param name="companyName"/>
	<xsl:param name="DEPARTMENT"/>
	<xsl:param name="moneyFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="amountFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="percentFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificMoneyFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificAmountFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificPercentFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificBonusPercentFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificDecimalFormatter"/>
	<xsl:param name="EMPID"/>
	<xsl:param name="FIRSTNAME"/>
	<xsl:param name="userName"/>
	<xsl:param name="LASTNAME"/>
	<xsl:param name="DIVISION"/>
	<xsl:param name="DISPLAYNAME"/>
	<xsl:param name="LOCATION"/>
	<xsl:param name="managerFirstName"/>
	<xsl:param name="managerLastName"/>
	<xsl:param name="TITLE"/>
	<xsl:decimal-format name="defaultDecimalFormatter" decimal-separator='.' grouping-separator=',' />
	<xsl:decimal-format name="decimalFormatterDotComma" decimal-separator=',' grouping-separator='.' />
	<xsl:decimal-format name="decimalFormatterSpaceComma" decimal-separator=',' grouping-separator=' ' />

 Declare company logo "we have to use company URL"

<xsl:variable name="companyLogoURL">
		<xsl:text disable-output-escaping="yes"><![CDATA[abc.jpg]]></xsl:text>
	</xsl:variable>
  • For adding company logo URL in custom statements, we must raise an incident to SAP.

Declare variables in compensation statements 

	<xsl:template match="/sf-compensation">
	<!--Variable Defnitions go here-->
		<xsl:variable name="empFirstName" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-plan-entry-firstname"/>
		<xsl:variable name="empLastName" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-plan-entry-lastname"/>
		<xsl:variable name="userId" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-plan-entry-userid"/>
  • If any custom field is created, then you can also use this approach â€“
 <xsl:variable name="customID" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-custom-data/comp-custom-field[@id='customID']"/>

 To Declare variable in Variable Pay Statements

 <xsl:variable name="customField1" select="vp-bonus-assignment/vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField1']"/>
    <xsl:variable name="customField2" select="vp-bonus-assignment/vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField2']"/>
    <xsl:variable name="customField3" select="vp-bonus-assignment[1]/vp-bonus-payout-item-list/vp-bonus-payout-item/vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField3']"/>
  • The first variable â€œcustomField1â€ is referring to variable present to ENTRY Level
  • The second variable â€œcustomField2" is referring to variable present on ASSIGNMENT Level.
  • The third variable â€œcustomField3 is referring to variable present on BUSINESS GOAL Level.

Declare all the CSS for the table, rows & column whichever is to be used in statements

.headerdetail {
font-size: 9pt;
font-family: Calibri;
margin-left:30px;
margin-top:20px;
margin-bottom:20px;
}
  • Here. headerdetail is a table used to display name and is explaining how CSS is defined for this table used in the statement
  • Font-size is 9, font- family is Calibri, Margin from left is 20 px , Margin from top os 20 px and from bottom its 20px.

Declaring a row 

<table class="headerdetail" valign="center" align="left" border="1px solid black" cellspacing="0" style="width:60%; border:1px solid black;padding-top:10px;border-collapse: collapse">
          <tr>
          <td valign="center" style="text-align:left; width:40%; border:1px solid black">
          <b><![CDATA[Name:]]></b>
          </td>

          <td valign="center" style="text-align:center; width:60%; border:1px solid black">
          <xsl:value-of select="$customDisplayName"/>
          </td>

          </tr>
          </table>
  • The table is displaying one row printing Name along the value of it.
  • customDisplayName is referring to employee name which is being pulled from worksheet
  • â€œ$ â€œis always used before any fieldID to pull the value of that field in statement.

To write any conditions,

<xsl:choose>
              <xsl:when test = "$customFlag = 'Yes' ">
            $<xsl:value-of select = "format-number(vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField1'], '#,##0.00')"/>
            </xsl:when>
             <xsl:when test="vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customPayoutPer'] > 0">
              $<xsl:value-of select="format-number(vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField2'], '#,##0.00')"/>
          </xsl:when>
            <xsl:otherwise>
             $<xsl:value-of select="format-number(vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField3', '#,##0.00')"/>
          </xsl:otherwise>
        </xsl:choose>
  • This code is saying that if there is any custom field as â€œcustomFlagâ€ and its value is equal to Yes, it will pull the value of customfield1 and print it
  • If â€œcustomFlagâ€is not equal to Yes and a custom field called â€œcustomPaypoutper is greater than 0 then the value of customField2 will be pulled
  • If both the condition is not fulfilled, then customField3 value will be printed

To maintain translation of different language

<xsl:template name="get-month-name">
		<xsl:param name="month"/>
		<xsl:param name="target_locale" select="en_US"/>
		<xsl:choose>
			<xsl:when test="$month = 1">
				<xsl:choose>
					<xsl:when test="$target_locale = 'es_ES'">Enero</xsl:when>
					<xsl:when test="$target_locale = 'pt_BR'">Janeiro</xsl:when>
					<xsl:when test="$target_locale = 'fr_CA'">janvier</xsl:when>
					<xsl:otherwise>Jan</xsl:otherwise>
				</xsl:choose>
			</xsl:when>
			</xsl:choose>
			</xsl:template>
  • The parameter target_locale is used for maintaining translations of different language.

    Conclusion: - 

    Implementing custom statements in sap SuccessFactors is more than a technical upgrade. By utilizing the flexibility of custom statements, organizations can present the compensation data in a way thatâ€™s clear, meaningful and aligned with the brand value.

entry.title: Re: No access to template in SAP for me
entry.content:
The reason why you are unable to raise request "Create Hyperscaler LB template for INBOUND traffic from an EXTERNAL source (Azure/AWS/GCP)" is because you don't have the necessary authorization to do so.

In order to submit a service request for the 'Create Hyperscaler LB template for INBOUND traffic from an EXTERNAL source (Azure/AWS/GCP)' template, an S-user must have the authorization 'Create Billable Service Requests' at the customer number level.

Upon reviewing your S-user ID, I found that the required authorization was only assigned at the installation level. Usually, you will need to contact your administrator listed in Users & Contacts - SAP for Me to have the authorization assigned.

For more detailed information on S-user authorizations required the Private Cloud Service Request application, please refer to KBA 2669783 - S-user authorizations required for the Private Cloud Service Request application - SAP for... 

If you encounter any further difficulties or require additional assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us.

Have a nice day!

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Market Segment Planning using Extension fields with B...
entry.content:
Hello @suyoung_choi3 

Thank you for your email.

To enable you upload Market Segment planning data you must ensure that the field is correctly extended and configured for plan data import. People commonly encounter issues that include technical name mismatches and unsupported business contexts or when there is a lack of proper alignment of plan and actual data for CO-PA because this uses different suffixes. If the technical name does not include the correct suffix or is not released for planning, SAP will treat it as invalid and fail the upload.

You can fix this through Field Extension for Planning. For that go to the Custom Fields and Logic app and check that YY1_SalesTeam is released for the planning business context. If the field is only released for your actuals and not for the plan data, then re-create or adjust it and make sure Planning is enabled during the setup.

Ensure the chosen technical name and suffix is correct. You should check the template downloaded from the app, make sure the field matches the technical that is required by SAP. For the custom characteristics, the correct name often ends with a plan-related suffix.

Ensure you date format and template is correct. For this download the planning data template directly from the Import app F1711, make sure you use SAPâ€™s recommended separators. Then map the columns exactly as shown in the template. Do not alter the fields that are mandatory.

See the following links for more details.

See SAP KBA 3427462

CO-PA Planning with Custom Fields

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3427462

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Technical background of the number of WBS element reg...
entry.content:
SAP Note 206264 is primarily concerned with system performance, not syntax errors. It warns that Projects with very large structures (e.g., >10,000 WBS elements) can cause long runtimes, Timeouts, Memory overflows, Dump errors during reporting (e.g., CN41, CN43N). These issues often appear during reporting or mass processing, not during creation.

Having said that, limit 9999 is not a hard system-enforced cap that triggers an error in a specific transaction. Instead, it is a technical recommendation. It could be that if you are using a coding mask to structure WBS elements (e.g., PROJ-001-0001), each level may be defined with a fixed number of digits. For example, if level 3 is defined with 4 digits, you can only go from 0001 to 9999. Exceeding this would violate the mask format, but only if the mask is enforced. If your system allows free-form WBS element names or uses non-restrictive masks, you can technically create more than 9,999 elements at a level.

So, to conclude, SAP's recommendation is only preventive, not enforced by default. In fact, reports like CN41 or CN43N are designed to navigate the hierarchical structure of WBS elements. When the WBS structure becomes too large, several technical bottlenecks emerge, and one example is memory consumption. SAP builds the entire WBS hierarchy in internal tables during report execution. With >10,000 elements per level, the system may exceed memory limits, especially in older ECC setups. This can lead to short dumps (e.g., TSV_TNEW_PAGE_ALLOC_FAILED or SYSTEM_NO_ROLL).

entry.title: Re: Rebate and Royalties in SAP S/4
entry.content:
Yes, Settlement Management typically generate Settlement Management Documents, not SD billing documents. These are stored in tables like CCS_D_SETTLEMENT and not in VBRK, which is specific to SD billing.

As regards Royalties, they rely on SD billing documents (VBRK/VBRP) to determine business volume. If your rebate settlement is not generating an SD billing document, it won't be included in the royalty calculation.

To include rebate amounts in royalty settlements, please ensure that Rebate settlement generates SD billing documents. You can configure in such a way that the rebate condition contract to use SD settlement rather than just accounting postings. In the condition contract type like 0S10, check if the Settlement Type is set to generate SD billing documents like SD01 or similar.

Configure Business Volume determination to include both SD billing and rebate settlements. SAP allows combined settlement where multiple condition contracts (e.g., rebate and royalty) can be settled together or linked via business volume.

entry.title: Re: This app is not enabled for key user adaptation
entry.content:
Hello @RaghavanKathamuthu 

Thank you for your question.

Please note, not every Fiori app is enabled for Key User Extensibility for example UI adaption at runtime, in the Public Cloud. You will need to assign roles SAP_UI_FLEX_KEY_USER to give you the authorization to perform that adaptation. However, if the app itself is not whitelisted for your UI adaptation, that will trigger the error you are experiencing. This behaviour is common and expected for certain apps, especially for analytical or object pages that SAP has not released for key user extensibility.

I suggest you check the extensibility catalogue in the custom fields to verify if the app you want to adapt is listed for extension. You can also use the SAP extensibility explorer for this.

After confirming and if the app is extensible assign the role mentioned earlier, ensure to clear cache, log off and try again.

Using Side-by-Side extensibility in BTP will be an option If the app is not extensible. You can access this through SAP Build Apps or make use of In-App Extensibility.

If non of the above-mentioned works, consider raising a ticket to SAP for more support.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud app get selection row
entry.content:
Hello @JamesG 

Thank you for reaching out to the SAP Community and your questions

Here are the two clean patterns for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition (Fiori elements, OData V4):

List Report (table selection)

onCustomAction: function () {

  const extApi = this.base.getExtensionAPI();

  const ctxs = extApi.getSelectedContexts();           // v4 Context[]

  if (!ctxs.length) { sap.m.MessageBox.warning("Select a row first."); return; }

  const rowData = ctxs[0].getObject();                 // plain JS object

  // ...use rowData (or ctxs.map(c => c.getObject()) for multi-select)

}

Object Page

onCustomOPAction: function () {

  const ctx = this.base.getExtensionAPI().getBindingContext();

  if (!ctx) { return; }

  const obj = ctx.getObject();                         // header data

}

 

If you require rows from a specific sub-table on the Object Page:

const selected = this.base.getExtensionAPI().getSelectedContexts("MyStableTableID");

const firstRow = selected[0]?.getObject();

Check below SAP references

SAPUI5 Demo Kit  sap.fe.core.ExtensionAPI (OData V4): API offering getSelectedContexts() and getBindingContext() methods for List Report and Object Page controllersâ€™ extensions. SAPUI5 SDK-Discover New Enterprise Grade Horizons

SAP Help Portal Using the extension API (Fiori elements V4): When and where to utilise the Extension API in controller extensions. SAP Help Portal-Using the extension API

Let me know if you need further information

Best regards,
Chuma

entry.title: Re: Distribution Channel set-up cause issue in DRF Replic...
entry.content:
Hi,

It seems that there's a concept supported by the SAP standard called a cross-functional distribution channel. By using it, you can save database space by assigning your customers and products to this cross-functional DC, which can then be used across all specific distribution channels.

So far, so good. However, if your customizing does not also enable the Sales View for this cross-functional DC (and in our case, we do not want to create Sales Orders using the cross-functional DC), then the Sales Arrangement data (i.e., Sales View-specific data) of your Business Partner (BuPa) will not be replicated via DRF to the S/4 clients.

So far, I haven't found any BAdI that would allow us to include our cross-functional DC as a valid combination. However, if you activate it in customizing, the replication of Sales Arrangement data works. Of course, this solution comes with some issues, and I would definitely prefer to solve this via a BAdI â€” so let's see.

Best regards,
Milan

entry.title: SAP Green Token for EUDR: Simplifying Compliance at Scale
entry.content:
The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is reshaping how companies source and trade key commodities in the EU. From December 2025, large companies trading commodities such as cocoa, palm oil, soy, rubber, cattle, coffee, and timber must prove their products are deforestation-free. SMEs will follow by June 2026.

The stakes are high. Non-compliance can mean fines of up to 4% of annual EU turnover, blocked shipments, exclusion from public tenders, and long-term reputational damage. Yet most companies are not ready for the deep traceability that EUDR requires, right down to the plot of land where commodities originate.

This is where SAP Green Tokencomes in.

Who is affected by EUDR?

The regulation applies broadly across the supply chain:

  • First-time Operators: Companies that first place commodities on the EU market or export them from the EU. First-time operators must perform full due diligence: collecting data (Article 9), conducting risk assessments (Article 10), mitigating risks (Article 11), and DDS creation & management (Article 4).
  • Downstream Operators & Traders: Companies that make relevant products available in the EU market after they have been placed there. Their obligations focus on record-keeping and referencing upstream due diligence statements (DDS) (Article 4 + 5).
  • Non-EU Suppliers: Not directly liable under EUDR, but they must provide EU customers with verified sustainability data according to Article 9 (geolocation, deforestation-free declarations) or risk losing access to EU supply chains.

This wide scope means global coordination across suppliers, producers, importers, and traders is essential.

 Figure 1. Why EUDR matters

Why DDS Management is the Cornerstone

At the heart of EUDR compliance lies Due Diligence Statement (DDS) management. Every operator and trader, regardless of role, must handle DDS in some form:

  • Article 4 (Operators): Operators must create and submit DDS in TRACES, ensuring products are deforestation-free and legally produced.
  • Article 5 (Traders): Traders must manage and reference upstream DDS, keeping records to prove that due diligence was exercised earlier in the chain.
  • Article 9 (Information Requirements): Defines the detailed data each DDS must contain: from geolocation of plots of land to production details, supplier information, and legality declarations.

DDS must be submitted in the EUâ€™s TRACES system and retained for at least five years. Without robust DDS management, companies cannot prove compliance, making it the true cornerstone of any EUDR strategy.
 

Why annual reporting is too risky

Some companies consider preparing one DDS per year to cover all volumes. On paper, this looks simpler. In reality, it creates risk:

  • One bad shipment could invalidate the entire batch.
  • Annual aggregation makes it harder to trace products back to individual plots of land.
  • Errors may only surface months later, when itâ€™s too late to correct them without penalties.
  • Fixed annual DDS volumes may be â€œused upâ€ too early, forcing resubmissions mid-year.
  • And critically: geolocation data must be collected for each batch regardless. Even if reported annually, the effort is the same â€” while exposing companies to much higher compliance risk.

In contrast, transactional reporting is safer and more agile:

  • Each shipment is tracked individually, limiting exposure if an issue arises.
  • Errors are detected early, reducing compliance risk and correction costs.
  • Companies maintain continuous oversight instead of year-end surprises.

This is why SAP Green Token is purpose-built for transaction-level traceability and not annual summaries.

 Figure 2. Green Token - Inbounds overview for EUDR

How SAP Green Token simplifies EUDR compliance

Green Token was designed to help companies comply with material accounting standards, such as EUDR, at scale. Hereâ€™s how:

  • Transactional-level reporting
    Captures data at the delivery level, linking each shipment to origin, sustainability data, and geolocation.
  • Built-in TRACES integration
    Automatically generates DDS, submits them into TRACES, and retrieves reference numbers back into Green Token.
  • Chain-of-custody management
    Maintains segregated accounting for multi-tier, multi-site supply chains, ensuring full auditability.  Because EUDR requires strict segregation of compliant and non-compliant flows, Green Token makes this process automated and auditable.
  • Open API for geo-spatial- and risk tools
    Connects with external geospatial and risk assessment platforms via GeoJSON, enabling Article 10 risk analysis.
  • Audit-ready by design
    Stores DDS and supporting data for 5+ years, with transparent reporting and real-time visibility for inspections.
  • Support for EU and non-EU companies
    Green Token supports operators, traders, authorized representatives, and even non-EU suppliers, enabling them to provide the data EU customers need.

The result: compliance becomes a continuous, automated process, not a manual, reactive scramble.

How it works in practice

Implementing Green Token for EUDR follows five simple steps:

  1. Capture delivery data from ERP or CSV sources.
  2. Map EUDR attributes (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS reference numbers).
  3. Generate DDS automatically in the correct TRACES format.
  4. Integrate with TRACES to submit DDS and pull official DDS reference numbers back into Green Token.
  5. Store and report data for auditing, with full transaction-level granularity.

This streamlined approach makes it possible for even complex, global supply chains to stay compliant without creating parallel systems or manual overhead.

 Figure 3. Green Token - Set Up Overview

Why SAP Green Token is different 

While other solutions focus narrowly on risk assessment or certificates, SAP Green Token delivers enterprise-scale compliance:

  • Transactional-level EUDR attributes & reporting: One of the few solutions that captures DDS data (geolocation, supplier IDs, DDS references) at the shipment/delivery level, instead of relying on aggregated annual reports.
  • ERP-native integration: Reuse supplier, material, and delivery data directly from SAP ERP, no duplicate entries.
  • Scalable for complexity: Handle multi-site, multi-commodity flows and adapt to evolving regulations like EUDR and CBAM.
  • Future-proof: Already supporting Authorized Representatives (Article 6) and ready to adapt to Omnibus updates.
  • Trusted partner ecosystem: Connect with external geospatial and audit partners through open APIs.

Only SAP Green Token combines transactional granularity, DDS Management, TRACES integration, and ERP-native scalability in one platform.

EUDR is not just another compliance exercise. Itâ€™s a structural shift in how companies prove sustainability across global supply chains. For operators, traders, and suppliers alike, the key to compliance lies in accurate, auditable, and automated DDS management.

Thatâ€™s why SAP Green Token is the starting point to make it happen.

ğŸ‘‰Ready to simplify EUDR compliance across your supply chain? Explore SAP Green Token.

entry.title: GRC Tuesdays: All (Tax and Trade) Routes Lead to Rome
entry.content:
Itâ€™s undeniable that challenges associated to trading routes have increased with changing weather conditions such as reduced water levels in Panama Canal, decreased safety around major shipping nodes with attacks on ships in the Red Sea or piracy acts in the Strait of Malacca, economical and geopolitical instability with import tariff hikes of course, and more.

But one thing is sure: for Tax and Trade best practices, all routes safely lead to Rome. At least for this yearâ€™s SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference, held on November 12-13th in the Eternal City.

Themed around â€œResilience in Motion: Adapting to a Shifting Worldâ€, the conference will be addressing many challenges that organizations face today, including:

  • How tax experts can eliminate manual interventions, reduce risks, and streamline compliance with minimal effort
  • How to increase transparency, reduce non-compliance issues, simplify IT landscapes and increase agility to respond to new regulations
  • Enable smarter, more transparent tax management with scenario analysis, automation, and a single source of truth
  • How to streamline global trade operations to accelerate cross-border processing, and minimize costs and risks
  • Stay ahead of tariffs, sanctions and global trade challenges in a shifting world
  • Optimize end-to-end supply chain processes to enhance visibility in trade operations, achieve duty savings, and leverage self-filing for greater efficiency

 

Opening keynote

 

Setting the scene for our 2 days, the opening keynote by the Chartered Institute of Export and International Trade will provide a comprehensive overview of the key challenges and developments shaping todayâ€™s trade and customs landscape. Set against the backdrop of ongoing trade facilitation, compliance requirements, and trade defence measures, this session will delve into the complex dynamics businesses face in navigating global trade.

 

Customer and partner stories

 

As in previous years, most of the conference will of course revolve around customer and partner stories with representatives from:

 

& more to be announced

Here, you can gain tangible examples of successful real-world scenarios from experienced organizations, with numerous tax and trade topics covered including:

 

Tax business cases

 

 

 

o   Document Reporting Compliance in the Digital Age: Navigating an Ever-Evolving Landscape

o   Inside Siemensâ€™ SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Roll Out: Challenges, Insights and Successes

o   A Solution that Sticks: tesa's SAP Rollout Across Latin America

o   Navigating the VAT Determination Journey to SAP S/4HANA Using SAP BTP

o   All Roads Lead to Compliance: Navigating Global Tax Complexity in your SAP Environment

o   Streamlining e-invoicing: How to Leverage SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

o   The Role Tax has Played in Driving the Transformation Agenda during Discovery & Beyond

o   Beyond the SAP Roadmap: Extending SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for Global E-Invoicing

o   Tax Transformation at Boehringer Ingelheim: Driving Global Compliance Through Standardisation and Automation

o   Accelerating Compliance and Efficiency: Migration to SAP S/4HANA and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

 

o   Co-innovation Session with SAP: SAP GTS Localisation for Mexico and Brazil

o   Navigating Global Trade Complexities: A Case Study with SAP GTS Solutions

o   Lessons in Implementing SAP Global Trade Services (GTS)

o   A Customerâ€™s Journey with SAP Watch List Screening: Strengthening Compliance and Boosting Efficiency

o   Optimising Import and Export Management with SAP Global Trade Services

o   Technology within Trade: Journey to E4H and Trade Classifier

o   Global Trade Compliance: Accelleron's Migration to SAP GTS Edition for SAP HANA 2023 on SAP RISE

o   â€¦ with more to come as we are still confirming some of the sessions!

Trade testimonials

 

 

 

Masterclasses

 

Masterclasses have been trialled â€“ and adopted! â€“ already at the Global Trade and Tax Conference last year. Designed for attendees seeking a deeper understanding of specific SAP solutions, Masterclasses are interactive sessions where you will have the opportunity to hear detailed insights directly from experts and ask any questions you may have.

2 Masterclasses are currently planned and more might be added as we see increased interest from both attendees and partners:

  • Live Demonstration: Ryanâ€™s NextGen Withholding Tax Automation Solution with SAP BTP, delivered by Ryan
  • Reframing Sanctioned Party List (SPL) Screening in SAP GTS: From Legal Obligation to Strategic Advantage, presented by Pinary

 

SAP keynote, live demos and roadmap sessions

 

Kicking off the event with an exploration of how cloud technology, AI, and predictive analytics can empower businesses to not just survive but thrive in this dynamic environment of geopolitical shifts, evolving regulations, and supply chain disruptions, SAP experts in Product Management will close the conference with an overview of the latest enhancements, upcoming features, and future innovations in SAP Global Trade Services and SAP global tax management solutions.

In addition, there will also be live demos by SAP Product Management colleagues showcasing product classification by similarity, product classification by semantic understanding & legal reasoning using Generative AI, but also management of e-document processing and statutory reporting requirements with greater efficiency and control.

 

Wondering what type of content you can expect?

 

First things first: this is really a business event, designed for tax and trade practitioners to share best practices.

For instance, at a previous edition of the event, Henkel shared an insightful deep dive into how they streamlined their global trade operations using SAP Global Trade Services to move goods in a truly global business model. Their presentation illustrated how the companyâ€™s decision to embrace SAP Global Trade Services has transformed its global trade operations, increasing both business value and agility and went into some details of how the company meticulously planned and executed this global project. All with a timeline for the rollout that centred around two key elements: global scalability and agility.

 

Still not enough?

 

What about a special Women in Tech business networking lunch and evening event to enjoy Italyâ€™s renowned culinary heritage in the very heart of Rome?

At the lunch break on the first day, PwC will host a special Women in Tech business networking lunch on the topic of â€œOvercoming diversity challenges in the world of technologyâ€. This is the perfect opportunity to connect with inspiring leaders, share insights, and foster valuable relationships with fellow women professionals in the tech and finance space.

At the end of the first day, unwind after a packed day of learning and networking at our complimentary evening event, hosted by Thomson Reuters at the stylish Casa Novecento. Located in the heart of Rome, just steps from the obelisk, Casa Novecento blends tradition and modernity and will offer delegates a relaxed evening of Italian cuisine, refreshing drinks, and great company.

 

Interested in learning more about SAP for Global Trade and Tax Conference 2025?

 

If you are looking for more details, then head straight to one of the links below where youâ€™ll find much more information than the summary shared in this short blog:

  • Event home page
  • Detailed agenda
  • Book your ticket

I really hope to see you at the event and, in the meantime, I look forward to reading your thoughts and comments on this blog.

entry.title: Re: Line item number not 0010 is missing when MRP run
entry.content:
Try with MD01 instead of MD01N, where ensure the following input parameters are maintained

  • Planning Mode = 3 (as you tried).
  • Create Purchase Requisitions = 2 (automatically).
  • Processing Key = NETCH (Net Change).

In MD01N, all the above fields may not be visible.  Even after executing MD01, if you have issue, one final test what you can perform is, execute MD02, for the problematic material. Check if the PR is created but not linked to a valid source list or info record, which might affect item visibility.

With all these, if your issue is not resolved, then, obviously, it could be due to some custom validation. Take the help of ABAP team and perform the above steps in debug mode to find out the root cause.
